alert.note: Alert for Lewis (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 28 at 1:38PM PST until March 02 at 2:35AM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Seattle WA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Washington... Chehalis River Above Doty affecting Lewis County. Newaukum River Near Chehalis affecting Lewis County. Chehalis River Above Grand Mound affecting Grays Harbor and Thurston Counties. .A strong storm is coming in to western Washington with multiple factors that will produce high runoff and flooding. Heavy, prolonged rainfall will be coupled with some snow snow melt in low to mid elevations of the mountains from rising snow levels and strong warm and moist winds. This will drive some rivers above minor to moderate flooding. Other points in the Chehalis River Basin may yet rise above flood stage as well. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT TO EARLY WEDNESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Newaukum River Near Chehalis. * WHEN...From late tonight to early Wednesday morning. * IMPACTS...At 204.5 feet, deep and hazardous flood waters will inundate many roads and residential and commercial areas along the Newaukum River and its forks. Impacted roadways and surrounding areas include SR 508, Jackson Hwy. and Tune, Rush, Sommerville, Griel, Hamilton, Tauscher, Guerrier, Kirkland, Macomber, Rice, Senn, Lucas Creek, Middle Fork and North Fork, Bishop, Shorey, Labree, Gish, Yates Roads. A stage of 204.5 feet on the Newaukum roughly corresponds to Phase 3 flood in the Lewis County flood system. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:45 PM PST Monday the stage was 198.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to a crest of 204.7 feet late tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 202.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this evening at 945 PM PST.
